stories.text:
I recently received unsolicited mail from a company (I'm in the US, and the company is also in the US) advertising their service.

I don't recall ever giving this company my name or address, so I contacted them and asked them to please let me know where they got my information from. They have not responded to multiple requests, so my question is: is there any legal action I can take to compel the company to reveal how they obtained my name and address?

It struck me that, while there are now numerous consumer protection laws around the country (and the world) which can require companies to reveal what information they have about you, or to delete your information, are there any laws anywhere which can compel a company to reveal how it obtained your information?
stories.title: Ask HN: How can I have companies reveal where they obtained my personal data?
The Worst Programming Language Ever – Mark Rendle – NDC Oslo 2021
SmoothWAN: Simple home internet multi-mode bonding router using Speedify

stories.text:
I decided to leave my boring 9-5 job and concentrate on a side project. Based on profits it was and is a no brainer, simply the right thing to do.

Now after about nearly 8 months, I really struggle. On the social part:

- kind of miss the boring big meetings - miss talk and argue with colleagues. Even with the annoying one. - The small battles were kind of fun, in retrospective.

and so on. Of course the obvious solution would be to get some employees. BUT I don't want to hire, only because I need a bit social interaction.

Anyone in a similar situation? Maybe I miss some obvious solutions. Would love to hear from you guys!
stories.title: Ask HN: One Person Company – Missing the social part
